titleStmt.title: INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE

affiliation.orgName: Institute of Clinical Psychology and Psychotherapy
Institute of Clinical Psychology and Psychotherapy

analytic.title: INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: In decision making, intolerance of uncertainty (IU) may be linked to safety behavior, which could ironically maintain IU and, thus, foster indecisiveness. In a smartphone-based experience sampling study, 247 participants described their real-life decisions six times per day and rated (a) their situational indecisiveness, (b) decision characteristics, (c) situational IU, and (d) problematic safety behaviors. Participants higher in dispositional IU reported more indecisiveness and engaged in more problematic safety behavior across measurements. The same relationships were observed with situational IU at the level of individual measurements. Engaging in more problematic safety behaviors during the first days predicted indecisiveness on the last day, mediated by IU. The results demonstrate the real-life relevance of the relationship between IU, indecisiveness, and safety behavior.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Decision making is indispensable for functioning in a world of increasingly complex choices. Accordingly, indecisiveness, a "trait-like difficulty making decisions across time and situations" (Lauderdale & Oakes, 2021, p. 256), is perceived as problematic in many cultures (Yates et al., 2010).

Indecisiveness is associated with impairment in everyday life, for example, putting off important tasks (Ferrari, 1994) or lack of commitment to academic goals (Germeijs & De Boeck, 2002), and with various mental disorders, such as obsessive-compulsive disorder (e.g., Frost & Shows, 1993) or anxiety disorders (Rassin & Muris, 2005). Potential explanations for the emergence of indecisiveness are multifaceted (van Randenborgh et al., 2010) and poorly understood (Lauderdale & Oakes, 2021).

One possible explanation for indecisiveness could be uncertainty and how it is handled. Decisions making often requires committing to a choice despite uncertainty. Notably, individuals differ in how much they "react negatively on an emotional, cognitive, and behavioral level to uncertain situations and events" (Dugas et al., 2004, p. 143), a trait called intolerance of uncertainty (IU;Freeston et al., 1994).

Faced with a decision, a person high in IU may strive to reduce uncertainty as much as possible, even to a point where the costs outweigh the benefits (Jacoby, 2020), for example, by spending more time on searching for information than the decision outcome is worth. In fact, excessive uncertainty reduction may maintain IU in the long run because it reinforces a pattern where uncertainty is not tolerated buton the contrary-treated as something potentially dangerous and to be avoided (Carleton et al., 2019).

This maintenance of IU, in turn, would then contribute to further indecisiveness in future decisions (Dugas & Robichaud, 2007). Previous studies related to this reasoning have relied on either correlational cross-sectional designs (e.g., Koerner et al., 2017) or controlled, but somewhat artificial laboratorybased paradigms (e.g., Wake et al., 2022). While the designs of these previous studies offer important evidence on the decision-making relevance of IU, they do not allow conclusions on whether the INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 4 proposed relationships between IU, problematic uncertainty reduction, and indecisiveness exist in people's real decisions in everyday life.

The present research therefore investigates the relationships between IU, indecisiveness, and problematic uncertainty-reducing behavior using the experience sampling method (ESM). ESM studies measure the same variables repeatedly from the same participant, often referring to their immediate and real-life experiences (Larson & Csikszentmihalyi, 1983). As a specific advantage of the ESM approach, it allows testing whether predictions hold in a natural setting. Hence, the present study contributes to understanding problems in a ubiquitous area of human functioning, namely decision making; and, in doing so, it uses a methodology with particularly high external validity.

div.head: Intolerance of uncertainty, decision making, and related behavior
div.p: Uncertainty is usually an unpleasant emotional experience (Carleton, 2016), and particularly so for people high in IU (Freeston et al., 1994). Due to the obvious uncertainty in many decisions, IU is assumed to be a predisposing factor for indecisiveness (Rassin, 2007). In line with a predisposing role of IU for indecisiveness, a robust correlation between IU and indecisiveness has been shown repeatedly (e.g., Koerner et al., 2017;Rassin et al., 2007).

IU-related behavior may be an important component of the IU-indecisiveness association (Dugas & Robichaud, 2007). IU-related behavior is defined as behavior primarily aimed at reducing uncertainty, either by resolving it (e.g., through overcompensating strategies such as information seeking), or by avoiding it (e.g., through under-engaging strategies such as procrastination; Bottesi et al., 2019). These behaviors can occur in decision making (Dugas & Robichaud, 2007). Previous findings are compatible with this reasoning. For example, IU is correlated with more checking of visual input when deciding whether two geometric shapes are identical (Wake et al., 2022). Similarly, Jacoby et al. (2014) found that IU was associated with increased information sampling before deciding which of two colors was represented more often in a bag of beads. In line with IU-related avoidance behavior, higher IU is also INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 5 linked with a tendency to avoid a variable waiting time before choosing between two options in a gambling task. This is true even when avoiding the waiting time obviously reduces the value and probability of potential gains (Luhmann et al., 2011).

IU-related behaviors aimed at reducing uncertainty can be problematic because they are costly in terms of time, energy, or resources. For example, an individual high in IU may spend hours looking for information in order to eliminate uncertainty in a decision (e.g., which product to buy). The time and energy spent searching may easily outweigh the benefits of finding a better product (see Schwartz et al., 2002). Another, more consequential problem arising from IU-related uncertainty-reducing behaviors is that they may maintain the underlying intolerance when carried out excessively (e.g., Dugas & Robichaud, 2007). This maintaining process is comparable to safety behaviors in anxiety disorders. For example, a person with panic disorder may leave the house only when accompanied by their partner. In the short term, this reduces the fear associated with being outside alone. However, in the long term, the person's confidence is undermined and the thought of being outside alone will evoke even more anxiety (Blakey & Abramowitz, 2016). Although IU in itself is not pathological, a similar mechanism may exist in IU-related behavior: Returning to the example of a high-IU individual seeking decisional information, this search may initially reduce uncertainty. However, persistent and excessive engagement in such behavior could diminish the person's ability to tolerate uncertainty in the future. In the long run, the person could depend more and more on uncertainty-reducing behaviors and become strongly averse to even small amounts of uncertainty in low-stake decisions. This vicious cycle would be fertile ground for indecisiveness. Figure 1 illustrates this proposed mechanism (cf., Jacoby, 2020).

div.head: Illustration of Predicted Relationships between IU, Safety Behavior, and Indecisiveness
div.p: Note. High levels of IU motivate a person to engage in uncertainty-reducing behaviors such as information seeking when faced with a decision. This behavior can take the form of problematic safety behavior, which, in the long-term, undermines the person's ability to tolerate uncertainty, or in other words, increases their IU. Increased IU, in turn, interferes with the uncertainty routinely involved in decision-making, thus promoting indecisiveness.

In the following, we use the term safety behavior when referring to excessive and problematic IUrelated behaviors aimed at reducing (decisional) uncertainty. In fact, psychotherapy programs targeting IU often focus on preventing safety behaviors (e.g., Hebert & Dugas, 2019), emphasizing their maintaining role. Dugas and Robichaud (2007) even refer explicitly to decision making and recommend the prevention of decisional safety behaviors in their IU-specific treatment program.

IU-related behavior, as well as its role as safety behavior (Tolin et al., 2003), has lately received increasing attention (Freeston et al., 2020;Wake et al., 2022). However, empirical research of IU-related behavior is still sparse (Bottesi et al., 2019), especially in the area of decision making. The few studies examining IU-related behavior in decision making (e.g., Jacoby et al., 2014;Wake et al., 2022) have not INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 7 been designed to test whether such behaviors meet all criteria of safety behaviors (Rosen & Knäuper, 2009). In the study by Wake et al. (2022), the increased checking of visual input before deciding is compatible with the notion of safety behavior. For example, it may resemble the exaggerated checking behavior of individuals with OCD. However, other criteria of safety behavior, such as disproportional effort and/or problematic long-term consequences cannot be inferred from the paradigm. Similarly, the choosing of more immediate but less valuable options in order to avoid waiting time, as observed by Luhmann et al. (2011), may resemble avoidant safety behavior of socially anxious individuals foregoing an enjoyable event out of fear of talking to others. Still, in order to more confidently classify this choice pattern observed in the experiment as safety behavior, other criteria of safety behavior should be fulfilled. More specifically, it remains unclear whether the choice pattern avoidant of waiting time is in fact motivated by uncertainty reduction, or rather by some other process, such as impatience. In the current study, we have therefore made sure to directly assess defining features of IU-related safety behavior, like having disproportional costs, maintaining IU in the long term, and being motivated by uncertainty. Moreover, the studies looking at decision behavior associated with IU have been crosssectional, which hinders the examination of potential long-term consequences of this decision behavior.

In contrast, the ESM approach we used, being longitudinal, allows looking at temporal sequences. This affords testing whether preceding safety behavior predicts subsequent IU and indecisiveness, consistent with a long-term negative effect of safety behaviors.

div.head: Purpose of the Present Study
div.p: In summary, IU is associated with indecisiveness and, presumably, with safety behaviors in the decision-making context. However, decisional safety behaviors may contribute to the maintenance of IU in the long term, creating a vicious cycle. Maintained IU, in turn, may negatively influence indecisiveness (Figure 1). The present research tests the associations derived from this idea. Complementing preliminary evidence from questionnaire-and laboratory-based research, our study relies on ESM INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 8 assessment of real personal decisions, demonstrating the everyday life relevance of the research question. Additionally, in cases where no personal decision was reported, we presented participants with predefined decision scenarios and posed the same questions as when a personal decision was described. This approach allowed us to test whether findings for personal decisions would replicate in standardized hypothetical decisions. To overcome limitations of preceding studies, we also assessed the extent to which uncertainty-reducing behaviors actually met criteria in line with the definition of safety behavior. Furthermore, the longitudinal nature of ESM affords testing relationships over time.

Hypotheses involving IU were tested both on the within-person level (Level 1; relationships between variables on the state level at any given time point) and on the between-person level (Level 2; relationships between trait measures assessed at baseline and/or state measures averaged across all time points).

Our central hypotheses were that state IU (Level 1) is positively related to state indecisiveness (H1a), and safety behavior (H1b); and, likewise, that trait IU (Level 2) is positively related to averaged state indecisiveness (H2a), and averaged safety behavior (H2b). Consistent with the idea of safety behavior undermining the ability to tolerate uncertainty and, in turn, to make decisions, we predicted (on Level 2, variables were averaged across time points) that preceding safety behavior is positively related to subsequent state IU (H3a) and subsequent state indecisiveness (H3b), and that subsequent state IU mediates the relationship between preceding safety behavior and subsequent state indecisiveness (H3c). Figure 1 visualizes the basic model underlying these hypotheses.

Less central to our main research questions, but adding valuable insight, we put forward secondary hypotheses (HS). First, we predicted that trait IU is positively related to state IU averaged across all time points (Level 2, HS1). Although this association may appear obvious, it would support the validity of our state IU measurement in general, and underline the applicability of state IU to the decision-making context in particular, corroborating the role of IU for decision making. Furthermore, INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 9 according to recent theorizing (Freeston et al., 2020), IU might shape the perception of situations by increasing the perceived uncertainty. Consistent with this reasoning, we expected that trait IU is positively related to averaged decision-related uncertainty (Level 2, HS2). Finally, building on results from an earlier study (xxx [masked for peer review], 2021), we predicted that decision importance moderates the relationship between IU and indecisiveness, in that the relationship will be stronger for more important decisions, both for state IU and state indecisiveness at a given time point (Level 1; HS3a) and for the cross-level interaction between trait IU (Level 2), decision importance (Level 1), and state indecisiveness (Level 1; HS3b).

div.head: Method
div.p: In the Online Supplementary Materials (OSM), all data and analysis scripts required to reproduce the results are openly available, along with additional materials and analyses (https://t1p.de/5rbpi).

Study flow (https://t1p.de/zgcl4), hypotheses, and analysis plan (https://t1p.de/xlbah) were preregistered. Four minor deviations from the preregistration were necessary (e.g., renumbering of hypotheses) and a detailed description is provided in the OSM.

div.head: Power analysis and participants
div.p: According to a simulation-based power analysis (Lafit et al., 2021; for details, see https://t1p.de/zgcl4), we strived for a final N ≥ 200, providing sufficient power (80%) to test more complex hypotheses including the cross-level interaction between trait IU (Level 2) and decision importance (Level 1) in predicting state indecisiveness (HS3b), as found in a previous study (β = .11, N = 345; xxx [masked for peer review], 2021). To account for data loss due to data quality checks, we aimed to recruit at least 240 participants with complete baseline measurements. We advertised the study through social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter) (3 x 100 € and 10 x 30 €). To meet inclusion criteria, participants had to: be at least 18 years old; be fluent in German; have a smartphone with an iOS or Android operating system and a mobile data plan; pass the instruction comprehension questions; complete the baseline survey within one day after registration; provide at least one valid mobile survey. The final sample included N = 247 participants (mean age: 25.6; 81.0% female, 0.4% non-binary) with 98.0% having a university degree or qualification for university entrance. More descriptive information is provided in Table 1 (referring to Level 1) and Table 2 (referring to Level 2) as well as the OSM.

div.head: Procedure
div.p: Data collection took place from January to March 2022. After providing informed consent, participants were screened for the exclusion criteria (age, language, technical requirements). If they passed the screening, they were directed to a tutorial. The tutorial provided an annotated sample trial of a fictitious participant to serve as a model and to illustrate which types of decisions and uncertaintyreducing behaviors were being asked for. Comprehension tests served to check understanding of the instructions, using five questions such as "What kind of decisions should you provide at the beginning of each survey?"(Decisions I have faced or am facing myself [correct], General decisions that people may face [incorrect]). The test trial consisted of a regular trial in which participants could make themselves acquainted with the handling of the survey. It was not included in analysis. Those who passed the tests registered their smartphone with the signaling software (SurveySignal©), followed by the baseline assessment, where they indicated different trait-level variables (e.g., trait IU). At the end, they chose an individual starting time for the daily signals (any full hour between 6:00 AM and 10:00 AM CET).

Beginning on the second day after registration, participants were invited via SMS to complete six daily mobile surveys on seven consecutive days on their smartphones, with a reminder sent 15 minutes after the original signal if necessary.

div.head: INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE

div.p: A flowchart of the mobile survey is presented in Figure 2. In each mobile survey, participants described their most important decision since the last signal, allowing both pending and already completed decisions (hereafter called reported decision trials). If no decision was reported, they were provided with one of 40 everyday moral decision scenarios (Singer et al., 2019, hereafter called scenario trials). Scenarios served to compare how participants reacted to their real-life decisions versus standardized hypothetical decisions and also discouraged intentional underreporting of decisions.
Referring to their own decision or the scenario, participants answered questions related to the decision.

If participants reported decisional uncertainty, they also indicated their state IU and any uncertaintyreducing behaviors, as well as to what extent this behavior qualified as safety behavior. Mobile surveys were distributed pseudo-randomly by SurveySignal© during a 14-hour time frame with at least 90 minutes between signals. Signals had to be responded to within 75 minutes or else were disabled. The day after the last signal at 10:00 AM, a feedback survey was sent.

div.head: Figure 2
div.p: Flowchart of Mobile Survey

div.head: Measures
div.p: Descriptive statistics and internal consistencies for the principal measures are presented in Tables 1 and 2. Most mobile survey measures referred to the reported personal decision or the provided decision scenario, respectively. Their wording was therefore adapted to the type of trial. All wordings are provided in the preregistration codebook in the OSM. If no established German version of a measure was available, item translation was undertaken based on a thorough translation-back translation process (Brislin, 1970). Trait measures were included for analysis if at least 80% of items had been answered, which was always the case (0% missing values). For state measures, the minimum number of INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 13 items required to calculate the score varied (see preregistration), but was met in the vast majority of measurements (99.4%; only 55 of all state measurements combined could not be included in the analyses).

div.head: Trait Intolerance of Uncertainty
div.p: At baseline, participants completed the Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale (Freeston et al., 1994; German version by Gerlach et al., 2008). The German version has 18 items (e.g., "Unforeseen events upset me greatly"), answered on a scale from 1 (not at all characteristic of me) to 5 (entirely characteristic of me). The factor structure of the scale has been debated. In a shortened English version, a two-factor structure has been proposed (Carleton et al., 2007), distinguishing between inhibitory IU (being paralyzed by uncertainty) and prospective IU (being vigilant and cautious in the face of uncertainty). For the German version, a three-factor solution was deemed more appropriate, with a Constrained Action and Vigilance subscale corresponding largely to the Inhibitory and Prospective subscales, plus a third Stress subscale reflecting stress due to uncertainty (Gerlach et al., 2008). More recent research has favored one general IU factor (McEvoy et al., 2019). Therefore, we used the total score for the main analyses and repeated analyses using all subscales exploratorily.

div.head: State intolerance of uncertainty
div.p: State IU was assessed for each decision with an uncertainty score of 2 or higher (on a scale from 1 = not at all to 5 = very). Three items were adapted from the Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale, each representing a subscale of the German version (Items 6, 8, and 20;Gerlach et al., 2008, p. 194). The "Uncertainty makes/made me uneasy, anxious, or stressed in this decision"; "The smallest doubt can/could stop me from acting in this decision"; "It frustrates/frustrated me not having all the information I need/needed about this decision". Answers were collected on a scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).

div.head: Trait indecisiveness
div.p: Trait indecisiveness was measured using the 15 item Indecisiveness Scale (Frost & Shows, 1993), the most common measure of indecisiveness (Rassin, 2007). A sample item is "I often worry about making the wrong decision." Answers were collected on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).

div.head: State indecisiveness
div.p: State indecisiveness was assessed using three items adapted from the Indecisiveness Scale. We chose items that could be worded so that they referred to the decision at hand. The wordings for the three items were: "I worry/worried about making the wrong decision"; "I become/became anxious when making the decision"; "I try/tried to postpone the decision". The response scale was identical to the trait version.

div.head: Decision domains, decision features, and decisional uncertainty
div.p: Participants assigned each decision to one or more domains and rated it on defining features. The 13 eligible domains were based on a previous study in which participants described personal decisions (xxx [masked for peer review], 2021), for example, "work/education", "relationship/family", or "food/drink". A "other" option allowed free entry.
Items representing decision features were included that stemmed from the same previous study.

They had been generated based on published research (e.g., Franz & Kramer, 2010) to provide a comprehensive dimensional taxonomy of decision characteristics, comparable to other taxonomies characterizing situations (Rauthmann et al., 2014) or life events (Luhmann et al., 2020). Based on factor analysis (xxx [masked for peer review], 2021), five dimensions were identified, for example, Decision Importance (e.g., "The decision has/had important consequences") or Lack of Information ("I lack/lacked information about the options"). All dimensions are provided in Table 1. For the current study, the two items with the highest loadings on each factor were included, resulting in ten items. However, only
Decision Importance was included in the testing of hypothesis. Answers were provided on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).
Further, we added an item directly assessing decisional uncertainty ("To what extent do you feel uncertainty is/was involved in the decision?"), answered on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very).

div.head: INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 17
div.p: For each decision with an uncertainty score of 2 or higher (on a scale from 1 = not at all to 5 = very), participants provided a free entry description of what they had done to reduce uncertainty, if anything. Examples of participants' entries included, but were not limited to, seeking advice (e.g., "I asked my mother for advice"), distraction (e.g., "I distracted myself with my phone"), or cognitive strategies (e.g., "I ruminated"). After providing this description, participants rated the described behavior on eight items representing criteria of problematic safety behavior on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). Sample items included: "I behave like this because I feel uncertain";

"Acting differently would be difficult for me"; "This behavior restricts me". For example, if a participant indicated that they had asked for advice to reduce uncertainty, they rated the items referring to this because I feel uncertain"), while the third factor reflected Feeling Forced (two items, e.g., "Acting differently would be difficult for me"). Because a three-factor solution was neither theoretically anticipated, nor planned in the preregistration, it was only considered in exploratory analyses, while our main analyses used the total score of all safety behavior items.

div.head: Data quality
div.p: To ensure data quality, participants were admitted to the baseline survey only if they completed the tutorial, answered the five comprehension test questions correctly, and finished the test trial. More data quality checks were applied after survey completion: Surveys answered too quickly (< 30 seconds)

were excluded. We also excluded surveys that-due to technical errors-were sent between 12AM and 6AM, as well as surveys answered less than 15 minutes before the subsequent survey. Furthermore, two research assistants rated all decision and uncertainty reduction descriptions to ensure that they contained the requested content. Coder agreement was 98.5% for decisions and 99.7% for uncertaintyreducing behaviors. Cases of disagreement were resolved through discussion. Reported decision trials that clearly contained no decision description were discarded completely. Similarly, safety behavior scores referring to invalid uncertainty-reducing behavior descriptions were not considered. In the closing survey, participants indicated whether their data should be used for analysis or not ("In your honest opinion, should we use your data in this study for our analyses?", yes, no; Meade & Craig, 2012).
This information was used for sensitivity analyses, testing the robustness of results when excluding participants who answered "no". Results of the sensitivity analyses can be found in the OSM.
Frequencies of exclusions due to each data quality criterion are provided in the OSM (https://t1p.de/l8qct). All exclusion criteria were preregistered.

div.head: Data analytic strategy
div.p: Analyses were carried out in R (R Core Team, 2020). For hypotheses involving Level 1 variables, we estimated multilevel models with measurement occasions nested in participants using the lmerTest package (Kuznetsova et al., 2017) and Full Maximum Likelihood estimation. In these analyses, we first estimated random intercept models (i.e., only intercepts but not slopes were allowed to vary among Level 2 units). To test HS3a and b, predicting a moderation of the relationship between IU and indecisiveness by decision importance, we added interaction effects to the models in a second step. For all random intercept models, we then estimated the corresponding random slopes models (i.e., both intercepts and slopes were allowed to vary among Level 2 units). The more complex models were only reported if they converged properly and fit the data significantly better than the respective-less complex-random intercept model (as indicated by a significant chi-squared deviance test). This was the case in all but some exploratory analyses, therefore random slopes models are being reported unless otherwise stated. Degrees of freedom and p-values for fixed effects were calculated with Satterthwaite approximation. For hypotheses involving only Level 2 variables, simple OLS regression models were calculated. Mediation models were estimated using the lavaan package (Rosseel, 2012), using bootstrapped (1,000 resamples) bias-corrected 95% confidence intervals. In analyses involving IU and indecisiveness averaged across the last measurement day, we controlled for the respective trait measures (i.e., trait IU/indecisiveness). By doing so, we aimed to control noise due to individual differences, thus increasing precision. The level of significance was set to alpha = .05.

To compute scale scores, item responses were averaged within scales (or subscales). Additionally, for some analyses, Level 1 variables were aggregated by computing the mean of the scores across all ESM time-points. Level 2 variables were grand-mean centered by subtracting the sample mean score from each participant's mean score. Level 1 predictors were person-mean centered by subtracting the respective participant's mean score from each individual measurement score.

We tested hypotheses separately for surveys referring to participants' own decisions (reported decision trials) and decision scenarios (scenario trials Tables 3 and 5. As an exception, we did not consider scenario trials when testing whether preceding safety behavior would predict increased subsequent indecisiveness via increased IU (H3a -c). This exception was made because a potential influence of an earlier behavior on later perceptions was not plausible for hypothetical scenarios.

We also tested all predicted relationships using the subscales of our measures of IU and safety behavior exploratorily. Theoretical deliberations did not imply specific predictions for subscales, especially since for IU, the practical utility of subscales has been questioned (McEvoy et al., 2019), while for safety behavior, the measure was new and the validation of the multifactorial structure is still pending. Also on an exploratory level, we repeated the mediation analysis (preceding safety behavior predicts more subsequent indecisiveness via IU; H3c) adding the frequency of uncertainty-reducing behaviors as a variable. In doing so, we tested whether frequency would explain more or additional variance compared to how much these behaviors met criteria of problematic decisional safety behavior.

Further exploratory analyses involved testing the positive relationship between IU and state indecisiveness (H1a & H2a) as well as between IU and safety behavior (H1b & H2b) with state and trait IU included simultaneously as predictors on the within-person level (Level 1). This approach allowed us to test whether both predictors still predict the respective dependent variable even when the other predictor is statistically controlled for. Furthermore, we assessed the within-person (Level 1) association between each measurement of safety behavior and the following measurement of indecisiveness via the following measurement of IU (multilevel mediation). Although we assumed on theoretical grounds that preceding safety behavior could influence subsequent indecisiveness via IU only after a certain time (i.e., the first six measurement days, H3c), we thus tested whether this predicted influence would also be observable from one measurement occasion to the next.

div.head: Results
div.p: We analyzed 8,580 mobile surveys from 247 participants. Of the original 8,939 surveys, 359

(4.02%) were excluded according to the preregistered criteria, mostly due to duplicate entries. On average, participants provided data for 6.72 days during the ESM phase and 5.17 mobile surveys per day. More descriptive information for all variables can be found in the OSM.

div.head: Descriptive statistics of decisions in everyday life
div.p: Out of all mobile surveys, 44.4% referred to actual decisions, while 55.6% related to scenarios. On average, participants reported M = 15.59 (SD = 9.25) decisions. In 35.5% of reported decision trials (n = 1,346), participants also reported uncertainty-reducing behavior. Frequencies of decision domains (reported decision trials only) ranged between M = 2.16 (SD = 1.65) for Covid-related decisions and M = 7.34 (SD = 5.03) for time planning-related decisions for each participant. Figure 3 shows the absolute frequencies of selected categories for reported decision trials. On average, 2.2 categories per decision were selected, with only 5.9% of decisions being assigned the "other" category. The scores of state IU and indecisiveness had relatively low means and left-skewed distributions. The same was true for uncertainty. Descriptive information, including decision features, is provided in Table 1, and more details can be found in the OSM.

div.head: Figure 3
div.p: Absolute Frequencies of Decision Categories (Reported Decision Trials)

div.head: Hypotheses
div.p: For all hypothesis-testing analyses, reported decision trials of the full sample were considered. Note. Hyp. = Hypothesis; L1/2 = Level 1/2; avg. = averaged; dfs rounded to no decimals.

div.head: H3: Preceding safety behavior predicts more subsequent indecisiveness via IU
div.p: Preceding safety behavior was defined as the safety behavior scores averaged across the first six measurement days, and subsequent indecisiveness and IU were defined as the respective state scores averaged across the last measurement day. We first checked whether the preregistered power requirement for testing this hypothesis was met. This was the case, since sufficient participants (n = 126)

had provided at least one score of preceding safety behavior and at least one score of subsequent state indecisiveness and state IU. Statistics are specified in 16; all correlation coefficients are provided in the OSM, https://t1p.de/rmna4).

div.head: Effect of Preceding Safety Behavior on Subsequent Indecisiveness Mediated by Subsequent IU
div.p: Note. Preceding safety behavior (i.e., engaging in more problematic safety behavior on the first six measurement days) predicted more subsequent indecisiveness (i.e., state indecisiveness averaged across the last measurement day), which was significantly mediated by subsequent IU (i.e., state IU averaged across the last measurement day); control variables (i.e., trait-level versions of variables) are not displayed; 95% CI = bias-corrected bootstrapped confidence intervals.

div.head: Secondary hypotheses
div.p: In HS1, we predicted that people with higher IU at the trait level also experienced more state IU in everyday decisions. Consistent with the prediction, higher trait IU was associated with higher averaged state IU, b = 0.30, t(235) = 5.06, p < .001.

In HS2, the prediction was that people with higher trait IU also perceived more uncertainty in their daily decision making. In line with the hypothesis, trait IU was associated with more averaged uncertainty during a decision, b = 0.32, t(242) = 4.19, p < .001. Importantly, this relationship between trait IU and uncertainty was also found for scenario trials, b = 0.23, t(240) = 2.95, p = .004, featuring the same standardized decision scenarios for all participants.

Finally, we tested whether the association between IU and state indecisiveness was stronger in more important decisions (moderation effect, HS3). Contrary to the hypothesis, this was not the case when looking at state IU on Level 1, b = 0.02, t(2312.073) = 1.01, p = .312 (comparison of random intercept model with and without moderator: χ 2 (1) = 1.020, p = .312; HS3a). However, when looking at trait IU, the expected moderation effect was found: The relationship between trait IU (Level 2) and state indecisiveness (Level 1) was stronger for decisions perceived as more important (Level 1), as indicated by a significant cross-level interaction in the random slopes model, b = 0.09, t(3551.45) = 4.25, p < .001

(comparison of random intercept model with and without moderator: χ 2 (1) = 18.02, p < .001; HS3b). For scenario trials, this effect was only found in the sensitivity analyses, but not in the whole sample. Note. Hyp. = Hypothesis; L1/2 = Level 1/2; avg. = averaged; dfs rounded to no decimals.

div.head: Exploratory analyses
div.p: All hypothesis-testing analyses were repeated using the subscales of the trait and state version of the Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale, as described by Carleton et al. (2007) and Gerlach et al. (2008) Concerning our secondary hypotheses, results from the subscale-based analyses also largely replicated the main analyses. As an exception, the hypothesized positive relationship between trait and aggregated state IU (HS1) was not observed for the IU Vigilance subscale in the scenario trials of the sensitivity analysis, b = 0.10, t(203) = 1.27, p = .205.

Also, as opposed to the prediction of a positive relationship between trait IU and decisional uncertainty (HS2), this relationship was absent for the IU subscales of Stress, b = 0.11, t(207) = 1.79, p = .075, Vigilance, b = 0.12, t(207) = 1.71, p = .088, and Prospective IU, b = 0.13, t(207) = 1.80, p = .074, in scenario trials of the sensitivity analysis.

As for the hypothesis that the IU-indecisiveness association was stronger for more important decisions (HS3), on Level 1, most state IU subscales did not interact with decision importance to predict indecisiveness (maximum non-significant interaction term b = 0.02, t(1889.00) = 0.84, p = .403). This lack of an interaction was opposed to the hypothesis (HS3a), but in line with the total score-based results.

Results for the interaction of trait IU with decision importance to predict indecisiveness (cross-level interaction, HS3b) were mixed: The trait IU subscales Stress and Inhibitory IU showed the expected interaction, but the Constrained Action subscale showed the interaction only in some constellations, while the Vigilance and Prospective IU subscales never showed it (maximum non-significant interaction term b = 0.04, t(3262.65) = 1.95, p = .051).

We also investigated the potential impact of the frequency of available data points for aggregated state IU and safety behavior variables. This allows to decide whether only the safety behavior characteristics of uncertainty-reducing behaviors were crucial or whether the frequency of these behaviors also had to be considered. Correlations between the frequencies of available data points for a variable and the corresponding aggregated variable scores were small (e.g., aggregated safety behavior score and frequency: r = .14; aggregated state IU score and frequency: r = -.04; both referring to reported decision trials). The frequency of available safety behavior scores was only a significant Finally, we also investigated the mediation model (preceding safety behavior predicts more subsequent indecisiveness via IU, H3c, see Fig. 4) in a multilevel analysis. The within-person (Level 1) association between each measurement of safety behavior and the following measurement of state IU was significant, b = 0.15, 95% CI [0.07; 0.24], whereas the association with state indecisiveness was not, b = 0.06, 95% CI [-0.02; 0.14]. Thus, safety behavior predicted more state IU, but not more state indecisiveness at the next measurement. Consequently, the mediation model that did apply to safety behavior averaged across the first six survey days and state IU and state indecisiveness averaged across the last survey day did not apply to the multilevel perspective.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Being able to make decisions is crucial for successfully navigating everyday life. Understanding helpful vs. disadvantageous aspects is a prerequisite for improving decision problems. Our ESM-based observations reveal robust associations between IU, safety behavior, and decisional difficulties in real everyday decisions. While not allowing causal inferences, these findings add evidence to the oftenstated assumption that IU and safety behavior may be important factors to consider when looking for ways to alleviate indecisiveness (Dugas & Robichaud, 2007;Jacoby, 2020;Rassin, 2007).

div.head: Summary of results
div.p: Trait IU was positively associated with state indecisiveness. This observation complements existing research showing that trait IU is related to trait measures of indecisiveness (Koerner et al., 2017), and extends it to real-life decisions. Furthermore, the higher the trait IU, the more features of problematic safety behavior were ascribed to uncertainty-reducing behaviors. The direct measurement of safety behavior, taking into account its defining features described in the literature, is an important addition to the state of research. Existing studies of IU-related behaviors in decision making that could be interpreted as safety behaviors have not explicitly tested some crucial safety behavior criteria, like the costs of a behavior or whether it is motivated by the desire to reduce uncertainty (e.g., Luhmann et al., 2011;Wake et al., 2022).

The trait-level associations of trait IU with variables averaged across all measurement days were mirrored by the same associations based on state variables, that is, at a given measurement. This consistency suggests that similar mechanisms are at play not only trans-situationally, but also in individual decisional situations, reflecting the ubiquity of the connection between IU, indecisiveness, and decisional safety behaviors.

As shown in exploratory analyses, trait IU and state IU each still explained unique variance in state indecisiveness and safety behavior when entered simultaneously as predictors in the same model. This result is in line with previous research showing, for example, that situation-specific IU explains variance in psychological symptoms above and beyond trait IU (Mahoney & McEvoy, 2012). The finding suggests that although a higher general disposition towards IU (i.e., trait IU) already predicts more indecisiveness and decisional safety behavior in specific decisions, IU felt in this specific decision (i.e., state IU) additionally helps explain these reactions to the decision.

We also found that engaging in more problematic safety behavior throughout several days was associated with more indecisiveness at the end of the ESM phase. This association was mediated by IU at the end of the ESM phase. Although correlational, the time component in our analysis is in line with a cumulative effect of safety behavior undermining tolerance towards uncertainty and, in turn, contributing to indecisiveness (cf., Dugas & Robichaud, 2007). Interestingly, associations of subsequent state IU and indecisiveness with preceding safety behavior were stronger than with the respective trait measures of IU and indecisiveness. Exploratory analyses showed that the mere frequency of uncertaintyreducing behavior explained little to no variance in subsequent IU and indecisiveness. This shows that uncertainty-reducing behavior in itself need not be problematic and it is important to explicitly assess to what extent it represents problematic safety behavior. Although the detrimental effect of excessive uncertainty reduction has been theoretically assumed (e.g., Freeston et al., 2020;Jacoby, 2020;Tolin et al., 2003) and even underlies IU-focused interventions (e.g., Hebert & Dugas, 2019), we know of no prior longitudinal studies actually corroborating this claim.

When exploring the same mediation from a multilevel perspective (i.e., each measurement of safety behavior predicting the next measurement of state indecisiveness via IU), safety behavior explained variance in IU, but not in indecisiveness. This may support the theoretical reasoning that safety behavior exerts a stronger influence on later feelings, perceptions, and self-evaluations only after a certain period of cumulative exertion (see Deacon & Maack, 2008). However, experimental research manipulating IU-related safety behavior is needed to conclusively test its causal effects.

Interestingly, most results held not only for participants' real-life personal decisions, but also for decision scenarios participants were asked to imagine. This aspect provides a valuable addition to the actual experience sampling data because it generalizes the findings to more standardized decision situations, reducing the subjective component of decision perception.

Some interesting additional observations were made in line with our secondary hypotheses. First, the concept of situational IU (Mahoney & McEvoy, 2012) was used to measure state IU in specific decisions. The finding that trait IU predicted increased state IU in participants' real-life decisions underlines the applicability of IU to the decision-making context, as has been demonstrated for others contexts as well, for example, specific mental disorders (Thibodeau et al., 2015), or Covid (Scharmer et al., 2020).

Further, trait IU was positively related to perceived decisional uncertainty. Importantly, this result was not only observed in reported decision trials, but also in trials featuring standardized scenarios, which were the same for all participants. This outcome is in line with theoretical considerations that IU alters the perception of situations, involving an increased sensitivity towards uncertainty (Freeston et al., 2020). This phenomenon may be analogous to lower thresholds of threat perception in pathological anxiety (Bredemeier & Berenbaum, 2020).

Finally, as found in a preceding study (xxx [masked for peer review], 2021), the more important a decision, the closer the link between trait IU and aggregated state indecisiveness, suggesting a certain context-dependence of this relationship. However, the interaction effect was small and was not found for state IU and scenario trials. The existing but limited moderation by decision importance supports the view that although trait indecisiveness extends to trivial decisions (Frost & Shows, 1993), it is not entirely independent of perceived decision features such as importance (Rassin, 2007).

Regarding the exploratory analyses using IU subscales (Carleton et al., 2007;Gerlach et al., 2008), the most important observation is that results based on total scores applied to all subscales as well for the main hypotheses. Regarding the secondary hypotheses, we also observed mostly the same relationships when using the subscales as compared to the total scale. Some deviations occurred, mostly in scenario trials, but they did not consistently rely on a certain subscale. The lack of consistent subscalespecific effects may support factor-analytic findings suggesting that IU subscales have limited explanatory value compared to the total score (McEvoy et al., 2019).

Results for the subscales of safety behavior were also largely in line with those based on the total score. Only the Feeling Forced subscale did not produce the same relationships in isolated constellations. Explanations may be that the items were difficult to understand (they were both based on hypothetical thinking, e.g., "Acting differently would be difficult for me"), that reliability was too low (the items had the lowest within-person reliability of all subscales), or that they were not perceived by participants to belong to the same construct as the other items (which may be supported by the factor analysis showing low loadings in both the 1-and 2-factor solution, cf. https://t1p.de/l8qct). In summary, although the content-neutral safety behavior assessment is innovative and its validity has been shown (xxx [masked for peer review], 2023), future studies should strive to adjust and improve the exact item wording.

div.head: Descriptive observations of decision making in everyday life
div.p: To the authors' knowledge, no ESM study has assessed a comparable amount of decision-related information several times per day, making this research an important addition to the decision-making literature even beyond the specific hypotheses tested. In reported decision trials, participants described a wide range of decisions. Time planning was by far the most common type of decision category. Workand education-related decisions were somewhat more frequent than leisure and vacation-related decisions. Combining decisions concerning social contacts, family, and partners, more than a third of decisions were social in nature. To our surprise, Covid-related decisions were the least frequent category (5.0%) although data collection took place in a time when public worry about the pandemic was still high. Levels of indecisiveness, lack of information, uncertainty, and state IU were relatively low, overall. Interestingly, this pattern converges with a daily diary study conducted by Zander-Schellenberg et al. (2019). They also assessed decision ease, in other words, a reverse-coded proxy of the state indecisiveness measure in the current study. Ease scores had a high mean (5.23 on a scale from 1-7) and

were right-skewed, mirroring the distribution of state indecisiveness in our study. Somewhat in contrast to the rather low overall level of uncertainty and state IU/indecisiveness, more than a third of decisions involved uncertainty-reducing behaviors. Importantly, this does not automatically imply problematic safety behavior. Using the midpoint of the safety behavior scale (3 on a scale from 1-5) as a reference point, 39.8% of uncertainty-reducing behaviors in (reported) decisions had high safety behavior scores, which constituted 14.1% of all reported decision trials.

div.head: Strengths and limitations
div.p: One aspect setting these findings apart from earlier research is the use of ESM. Thus, results are not based on general retrospective self-evaluations as in existing correlational studies on IU, indecisiveness (e.g., Koerner et al., 2017), and related behaviors (e.g., Sauer et al., 2020). The fact that we observed all predicted associations using this methodology makes a strong case for their pervasiveness even in unselected samples with relatively low levels of decision problems, and is a crucial addition to converging findings from earlier studies (e.g., Wake et al., 2022).

In addition, existing ESM studies of decision making have looked at specific subtypes of decisions, like choices in self-control temptations (Hofmann et al., 2012) or food choices (Bauer et al., 2022).

Studies in which participants described their general decisions, however, have only included one measurement per day and provided limited descriptive data about the decisions (Bjälkebring et al., 2015;Sirota et al., 2018;Zander-Schellenberg et al., 2019). Thus, the present study also affords general The measurement of safety behavior also constitutes an innovation. Whereas preceding studies (e.g., Bottesi et al., 2019;Wake et al., 2022) only allowed indirect conclusions about the safety behavior status of IU-related behaviors, the present study explicitly included defining features of problematic safety behavior. Also, this approach ensures that all uncertainty-reducing behaviors provided by participants have a corresponding safety behavior score, generating a comprehensive collection.

Judging the data collection procedure, 82.9% of all signals were responded to with a valid survey, indicating good compliance (e.g., Hofmann & Patel, 2015). Crucially, surveys were distributed equally across all days of the week, including weekends, thus likely reflecting the full range of decisions.

Although participation was completely online, careful measures were taken to assure instruction comprehension, including a tutorial and mandatory attention checks. Also, underreporting of decisions was disincentivized by providing decision vignettes if participants had no personal decision to report.
These data quality criteria were reflected in a low rate of invalid decision descriptions (1.2%) and uncertainty reduction descriptions (0.2%) in the post-hoc external ratings.

Some limitations should be mentioned. The current sample was, on average, quite young and predominantly female, with a high education level. Future studies should strive for more representative samples to assure better generalizability. Importantly, however, trait IU levels, ranging from 2.67 (Constrained Action) to 2.99 (Stress) were comparable and even higher than in other (German speaking) unselected samples. For example, Sauer et al. (2020) found trait IU scores ranging from 2.36 (Constrained Action) to 2.77 (Vigilance and Stress) during the Covid pandemic. Crucially, the detected associations indicate that even in unselected samples, existing individual differences as well as withinperson variability meaningfully explain variance in indecisiveness and safety behaviors. This being said, future research may strive to replicate the present findings in clinical samples (cf., Khawaja & Yu, 2010) or those pre-selected according to their IU scores (cf., Wroblewski et al., 2022).

Although ESM data afford more conclusions than cross-sectional data by offering insight on the sequence of events, the reported findings are correlational. Ultimately, only experimental manipulations of the predictors included in this study would allow for causal inferences. For example, studies on the effects of pathological safety behavior have had participants carry out these behaviors for several days and observed the effects of these behaviors on subsequent pathology symptoms compared to a control condition (e.g., Deacon & Maack, 2008). Similar designs could be implemented with regard to IU, for example, using the pool of potential safety behaviors collected in this study, and observing their effect on subsequent IU. In a similar vein, IU could be experimentally manipulated (Rosser, 2019) to assess its causal effect on (state) indecisiveness (Rassin, 2007).

For the sake of capturing actual everyday decision making, daily surveys were collected with relatively high frequency during a rather short total measurement period. Consequently, our hypotheses involving a temporal sequence (H3a -c) could only be tested based on one sequence of safety behavior on the first six days and subsequent IU/indecisiveness on the last day. Testing shorter sequences (e.g., safety behavior on one day predicting other variables on the next day) seemed inadequate because the predicted effects of safety behavior cannot be expected to manifest themselves so fast (cf., Deacon & Maack, 2008). A survey schedule with a longer total measurement period (possibly with fewer daily measurements to avoid participant burden) would have provided more sequences per participant to test these predictions. However, fewer daily measurements would not have matched the high number of daily decisions we expected based on previous studies (e.g., Zander-Schellenberg et al., 2019).

Depending on which definition of decision is used, our study did certainly not capture all types of decisions. Although there is no evidence about the actual average number of daily decisions, research on food-related choices (Wansink & Sobal, 2007) suggests that people massively underestimate the number of decisions actually taking place (e.g., the micro-decisions of what, with whom, when, etc. to have dinner vs. the holistic decision of "What to do for dinner"). Having said this, our design choices served the primary goal of testing specific hypotheses. Future research primarily aiming at general insights about decision making might benefit from more frequent but shorter measurements.

Finally, although the connection to participants' real life is assured through the use of ESM, the data still rely on self-reports prone to typical biases like demand characteristics. It is therefore important to complement the current findings with behavioral data observed under controlled conditions.

However, building on earlier studies (e.g., Jacoby et al., 2014;Wake et al., 2022), but explicitly testing the safety behavior status of IU-related behaviors would be an important addition. The safety behavior items , having proved their usefulness in the present study and preceding research (xxx [masked for peer review], 2023), can be a helpful manipulation check tool.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The results have some practical implications. They add to the evidence that IU is an important factor in decision making and problems associated with it. Our observations also suggest that safety behavior, at a certain point, is not only costly, but may also contribute to the underlying problem of not being able to handle uncertainty. Accordingly, interventions against indecisiveness might benefit from strengthening uncertainty tolerance and reducing problematic decisional safety behaviors. Even in decision-making areas requiring high levels of precision, for example medical practice, uncertainty is inevitable and its adequate management is crucial (Simpkin & Schwartzstein, 2016). However, more research is needed to confirm causal mechanisms.

This research also makes several important contributions in advancing the understanding of IU and indecisiveness. First, our findings generally show that these traits are reflected in everyday decision behavior. In fact, this is the first ESM study involving indecisiveness and the first ESM study of general decision making with more than one measurement per day. More importantly, they demonstrate robust relationships between IU, indecisiveness, and safety behaviors in everyday life decision making. Finally, the results suggest that the vicious cycle found for safety behaviors in anxiety disorders may be INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 39 applicable to IU and decision making. Although this idea has been proposed theoretically (e.g., Dugas & Robichaud, 2007), the present data represent the most direct evidence to date. It goes beyond preceding studies due to a convincing operationalization taking into account the defining characteristics of safety behavior, and because our analyses considered the temporal sequence of variables.

The fact that all predicted relationships were found in real decisions made by an unselected sample is a strong indication of the ubiquity of these relationships. It shows that IU and problematic safety behavior, although often thought of as a clinical constructs, have implications for everyday behavior in non-clinical populations. This appears to be true not only for pathological phenomena, but also for a behavior as common as deciding.

insights into decision making in everyday life. It further offers a rich pool of real-life decision making and uncertainty reduction descriptions. It therefore provides valuable quantitative and qualitative information open for scientific use in future research.

figure.figDesc: uncertainty-reducing behavior. They thereby indicated to what extent they asked for advice because they felt uncertain; to what extent it would be difficult for them not to ask for advice and instead deal differently with the uncertainty; to what extent asking for advice restricted them, etc. Higher scores thus reflected that the reported uncertainty-reducing behavior fulfilled more criteria of problematic (decisional) safety behavior.The items were developed based on literature, mainly on anxiety disorders (e.g.,Helbig-Lang & Petermann, 2010;Thwaites & Freeston, 2005). Xxx [masked for peer review] (2023) provide details on the construction and validity of the items, demonstrating that they differentiate between adaptive behaviors and problematic safety behaviors in decision-making contexts. Crucially, in contrast to lists of specific safety behaviors (e.g.,Goodson et al., 2016), these items assess to what extent any uncertaintyreducing behavior qualifies as safety behavior (including cognitive "behaviors" like rumination). To explore the measure's factor structure in an ESM context, a multilevel exploratory factor analysis was conducted. Details are provided in the OSM (https://t1p.de/l8qct). Similarly, decisions with higher levels of state IU also tended to entail more problematic safety behaviors, b = 0.33, t(109.73) = 13.78, p < .001 (H1b). Both findings are consistent with predictions.

Descriptive Statistics for all subscales aggregated across reported decision trials are provided inTable 1. Detailed results including coefficients for all constellations can be found in the output files in the OSM.Regarding our primary hypotheses, all relationships were replicated across all IU and safety behavior subscales, with the following exceptions: the expected positive relationship between trait IU and aggregated safety behavior (H2b) did not emerge consistently for the safety behavior Feeling Forced subscale. For example, in reported decision trials and when considering the whole sample, trait IU did not predict the Feeling Forced subscale of safety behavior, b = 0.11, t(223) = 1.47, p = .143. When excluding data from participants stating we should not use their data (sensitivity analysis), trait IU did not predict the Feeling Forced subscale in both reported decision and scenario trials, maximum b = 0.15, t(196) = 1.87, p = .063. Similarly, in the mediation analysis regarding H3c (i.e., preceding safety behavior predicting increased subsequent indecisiveness via increased IU, cf.Fig. 4), the safety behavior Feeling Forced subscale (aggregated across the first six days) was not related to the mediator (i.e., state IU aggregated across the last day) in the full sample, b = 0.15, 95% CI [-0.10; 0.39], or in the sensitivity analysis, b = 0.15, 95% CI[-0.14; 0.37]. For all IU subscales and the safety behavior Feeling Forced subscale, the direct effect of safety behavior on indecisiveness when controlling for state IU remained significant, indicating partial mediation instead of the full mediation found for the total scale scores

INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE 30 predictor (b = 0.03, 95% CI [0.004; 0.06]) in the model of preceding safety behavior predicting more subsequent state indecisiveness (H3b), but not in the model of preceding safety behavior predicting subsequent state IU (H3a) or the mediation model (H3c; maximum b = 0.01, 95% CI [-0.02; 0.03]). Most importantly, none of the overall results of these models changed when including safety behavior frequency as a control variable. Detailed results are provided in the output files in the OSM.

div.head: Declaration of interests
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

div.head: Acknowledgment
div.p: We would like to express our gratitude and pay tribute to BE [abbr. for peer review], who inspired the research presented here and contributed important ideas during her tenure as a professor at the University of xx [masked. for peer review]. Sadly, she passed away prematurely.
We thank MH, HM, and CM [abbr. for peer review] for their help with data collection.

div.head: INTOLERANCE OF UNCERTAINTY, INDECISIVENESS, AND SAFETY BEHAVIOR IN EVERYDAY LIFE
Funding statement
div.p: This work was supported by Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG; German Research Foundation; grant number xxx [masked. for peer review]).

div.head: Open Practices
div.p: This research was preregistered. All research data, analysis scripts, codebooks, and preregistration protocols can be downloaded from https://t1p.de/5rbpi.
